Furthermore, good sons! Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten kinds of dharmas attain a vast mind.ğŸ”½What
are the ten?
First, I shall accumulate all the equal pÄramitÄs. This is called giving rise to a vast mind;
Second, I shall perfect all the Buddha Dharmas. This is called giving rise to a vast mind;
Third, I shall subdue all sentient beings. This is called giving rise to a vast mind;
Fourth, I shall sit at the site of enlightenment and manifest perfect enlightenment in unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment. This is called giving rise to a vast mind;

Fifth, having manifested perfect enlightenment, turning the wheel of the Dharma, if any Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, devas, mÄras, BrahmÄ, or worldly people are unable to turn it together with me, this is called giving rise to an expansive mind;

Sixth, for the sake of benefiting all sentient beings, going to immeasurable and boundless worlds to perform beneficial activities for those sentient beings, this is called giving rise to an expansive mind;
Seventh, I shall accumulate prajÃ±Ä as a boat and ferry all sentient beings in the ocean of birth and death to the other shore, this is called giving rise to an expansive mind;

Eighth, seeing that sentient beings have no master, no refuge, no rescue, no protection, and no place, I shall become their retinue and be their protector and so forth, this is called giving rise to an expansive mind;
Ninth, regarding all the Buddha's supreme activities, I shall manifest the ability to perform the Buddha's supreme activities;
the Buddha's lion's roar, I shall be able to make the great lion's roar;
the Buddha's play, I shall play;
the great dragon's observation, I shall observe;
what I attain, I shall cause all gods, demons, Brahmas, worlds, ascetics, Brahmins, and all worldly gods, humans, and non-humans to attain it, this is called giving rise to the vast mind;

tenth, the Buddha's great majestic virtue taming sentient beings, I shall tame, not acting coarsely, not acting unbeneficial suffering, not acting inferior, this is called giving rise to the vast mind.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten dharmas attain the vast mind.
Furthermore, good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten dharmas attain a pure mind.
What are the ten?
First, attaining a perfect intention, because this intention is immovable by nature, always abiding, and without pretense;

Second, being far removed from unreasonable thoughts, thinking I will make the lion's roar of a Buddha, never giving rise to the thoughts of Å›rÄvakas, never giving rise to the thoughts of pratyekabuddhas, and never giving rise to partial thoughts;
Third, being forever free from all dust and defilements, being able to remove the dust of afflictions;
Fourth, being forever free from the pretense of bodily displays, being able to be far removed from all the different appearances of pretentious conduct;
Fifth, being forever free from the pretense of speech, never displaying untrue speech;
Sixth, being forever free from the pretense of mental activity, because the body is unattached, because speech is content, and because the mind has no desires;
Seventh, repaying kindness. Always not forgetting even a small kindness, let alone many kindnesses that should be repaid.
Eighth, knowing kindness. To those who have been kind, there is no concealment, and they are not looked down upon.
Seeing their virtues, they rejoice and praise them, except for those in the world who are shameless.
Ninth, acting as one speaks. Bodhisattvas manifest beautiful words that accord with the mind.
The mind is always tranquil, harboring no resentment.
Respecting others, they do not give rise to contempt.
Speaking truthfully, without pretense.
They are not followed by stinginess, jealousy, flattery, or deception.
Bodhisattvas never cause others to fight, nor do they break others down one by one.
They speak the truth and give what is beneficial.

Tenth, they are forever free from slander within the teachings of the TathÄgata. This means that after these bodhisattvas have given rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment, they shave their heads and beards, don the kÄá¹£Äya robe, and with right faith leave the home-life to join the monastic order within the teachings of the TathÄgata. They do not do so because they are forced by the power of the king, nor are they coerced by thieves, nor do they join the monastic order as a means of avoiding debt, nor do they seek to leave the home-life out of fear, nor do they join the monastic order out of fear of not being able to make a living, nor do they join the monastic order with wrong livelihood, but rather they join the monastic order with faith in seeking the true Dharma.
Bodhisattvas always seek out good and wise advisors, associate with them, serve them, listen to the true Dharma, and after hearing it, practice it.
Moreover, bodhisattvas are not obscured by arrogance, because they are free from arrogance;
they do not grasp things in a distorted manner, because they have the nature of receiving things without distortion;
they realize the path of penetrating insight, because they attain penetrating insight;
they realize the nature of dharmas, because they attain the nature of dharmas.
Having realized the nature of dharmas, one is able to definitely attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
This is called the bodhisattva's freedom from slander of the Buddha's teachings.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten kinds of dharmas attain a pure mind.
Moreover, good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten kinds of dharmas attain a mind free from doubt.
What are the ten?
First, deeply believing in the TathÄgata's secret of physical actions;
Second, deeply believing in the TathÄgata's secret of verbal actions;
Third, deeply believing in the TathÄgata's secret of mental actions;
Fourth, deeply believing in the bodhisattvas' accumulation;
Fifth, deeply believing in enlightenment;
Sixth, being able to believe in the TathÄgata's appearance;
Seventh, being able to believe in the explanation of the true characteristics of the One Vehicle;
Eighth, being able to believe in the proclamation of various true characteristics;
Ninth, being able to believe in the TathÄgata's profound and far-reaching voice;
Tenth, deeply believing that the TathÄgata knows the inclinations of sentient beings and disciplines them.
How do bodhisattvas deeply believe in the TathÄgata's secret of physical actions?
Good man!

It means that if bodhisattvas hear of the nature of the TathÄgata's Dharma body, the nature of the tranquil body, the unequaled nature of the body, the immeasurable nature of the body, the uncommon nature of the body, and the vajra nature of the body, they think like this:
'This is true, not false.'
It means that this bodhisattva has no doubt in his mind about those dharmas. This is called the bodhisattvas' deep belief in the TathÄgata's secret of physical actions.
How do bodhisattvas deeply believe in the TathÄgata's secret of verbal actions?

It means that when bodhisattvas hear that the TathÄgata has already given predictions in person to sentient beings, given predictions without being present, and given secret predictions, the bodhisattvas think like this:
'The TathÄgata's words are never false, and there are no mistakes!'
For this reason, the Buddha's words are true.
Why is it so?
Because the TathÄgata has forever severed all faults, all defilements, all afflictions, and all passions, he is able to attain mastery, purity, and clarity, free from all impurities.
If the TathÄgata's words were false or erroneous, it would be impossible. Only this is true, not false.
The bodhisattva has no doubts about this teaching, which is called the bodhisattva's deep faith in the TathÄgata's secret of speech.
What is the bodhisattva's deep faith in the TathÄgata's secret of mind?

If bodhisattvas hear the secret of the TathÄgata's mind, namely that the TathÄgata's intentions, Dharma meanings, and bases are dependent on the mind, and abide in the mind, and that this cannot be known by any bodhisattvas, Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, or sentient beings, except by those empowered by the TathÄgata,
why is it so?

Because the TathÄgata is profound and difficult to fathom, beyond conceptualization and the domain of conceptualized practices, vast and immeasurable, like space, transcending the realms of all false conceptualizations.
The bodhisattva thus contemplates correctly:
'This is true, not false!'
In those dharmas, he attains freedom from doubt. This is called the bodhisattva's deep faith in the secret of the TathÄgata's mental activity.
What is meant by the bodhisattva's deep faith in accumulation?

It means hearing that the bodhisattvas directly benefit all sentient beings, and that whatever is to be done by those sentient beings they are able to do it all, never becoming weary, and also not becoming frightened.

Moreover, they are able to bear the heavy burden of great vows, have great power, are courageous and firm, are able to accumulate all the perfections, sequentially accumulate all the Buddha Dharmas, attain unobstructed cognition, cognition with boundless natures, cognition with unequaled natures, cognition with uncommon natures, are firm in effort, firm in donning armor, firm in vows, their vows are unshakable, their vows are uncommon, and they take these as the causes and conditions for unsurpassed enlightenment.
These bodhisattvas sequentially cultivate them, causing them to arise, grow, and become vast and great.
The bodhisattva thinks like this:
'This is true, not false!'
The bodhisattva attains non-doubt regarding those dharmas, and this is called the bodhisattva's ability to attain deep faith and accumulation.
How do bodhisattvas deeply believe in enlightenment and the appearance of the TathÄgatas?
Bodhisattvas think like this:
'It is said that when bodhisattvas sit at the site of enlightenment, they become unattached, unobstructed, and free from hindrances;

They attain the supernormal knowledge of the divine eye, the divine ear, the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of past lives, the knowledge of miraculous powers, and the knowledge of the destruction of defilements;
They accomplish supreme knowledge, and in each instant they penetrate the three times, unattached, unobstructed, and free from hindrances.
For this reason they are able to thoroughly observe the realm of sentient beings.

These sentient beings accomplish evil bodily actions, accomplish evil verbal actions, accomplish evil mental actions, receive various wrong teachings, give rise to wrong views, and slander the noble ones. For this reason, when their bodies perish and their lives end, they fall into evil destinies and are born in the hells.

They are also able to observe that such sentient beings, having accomplished good conduct of body, speech, and mind, receive the true Dharma, give rise to right views, do not slander the noble ones, and by these causes and conditions, after death, are reborn in the good destinies, attaining rebirth in the heavens.
The bodhisattva, having thus truly observed the good and bad karma of the realm of sentient beings, thinks like this:
'In the past, when I was practicing the conduct of a bodhisattva, I had such a vow:
If I can awaken myself and cause others to awaken,
then my vow will be fulfilled and my aspirations will be satisfied!
This is the truth, not false.'
The bodhisattva is able to attain non-doubt regarding those dharmas, and because of this, the bodhisattva is able to realize enlightenment and is called 'rightly awakened.'
Good man!
This is called the bodhisattva's deep faith in enlightenment and the appearance of the TathÄgata.
How does the bodhisattva deeply believe in the true aspect of the teaching of the One Vehicle?
That is to say, the bodhisattvas think like this:
'Having heard the TathÄgata's teaching of the One Vehicle, it is only true, not false, and is always unchanging.'
Why is it so?
Because all vehicles come out from the One Vehicle.
Good sons!
It is like in JambudvÄ«pa there are various small islands, although each has a different name, they are all the same in relying on JambudvÄ«pa, and therefore they are called 'one JambudvÄ«pa.'

The One Vehicle taught is also like this, because the TathÄgata Vehicle appears in all vehicles, and although the various vehicles have different names, they are all the same in relying on the TathÄgata Vehicle, and therefore it is called 'the One Vehicle.'
The bodhisattvas are able to attain non-doubt in that true Dharma, this is called the bodhisattvas' deep faith in expounding the true characteristic of the One Vehicle.
How are the bodhisattvas able to deeply believe in expounding the various true characteristics?
That is to say, the bodhisattvas think like this:
'Having heard that the Tathagata's sutras proclaim such various true characteristics, this alone is true, not false.'
Why is it so?
Because the Tathagatas are able to subdue, and expound the wonderful Dharma according to the various inclinations of sentient beings.
The bodhisattvas are able to be without doubt in this true Dharma, this is called the bodhisattvas' deep faith in the expounding of various true characteristics.
How do the bodhisattvas deeply believe that the Tathagata's voice is profound and far-reaching?
The bodhisattvas think like this:
'Having heard that the Tathagata's voice is profound and far-reaching, this alone is true, not false.'
Why is it so?

Because even the celestial sons with little merit and wholesome roots still attain a profound, beautiful, and wonderful voice, how much more so the Tathagata who has accumulated wonderful practices for innumerable hundreds of thousands of eons!
Therefore, bodhisattvas attain freedom from doubt regarding those dharmas. This is called the bodhisattvas' deep faith in the TathÄgata's far-reaching voice.
How do bodhisattvas attain deep faith in the TathÄgata's knowledge of sentient beings' inclinations and their taming?
Bodhisattvas think like this:

'It is heard that the TathÄgata can know the inclinations of all sentient beings, their various latent tendencies, and their various understandings, and with a single voice he expounds the Dharma, causing them all to be tamed, each according to their understanding, to eliminate doubts, and to bring sentient beings to maturity.
Each sentient being thinks like this:
Each thinks that the TathÄgata is expounding the wonderful Dharma exclusively for them.
The TathÄgata is truly without discrimination here, thinking 'I am the one who expounds, and sentient beings are the ones to be transformed.'
This is the truth, not a falsehood.
Bodhisattvas are able to attain freedom from doubt regarding those dharmas. This is called the bodhisattvas' deep faith in the TathÄgata's knowledge of sentient beings' inclinations and their taming.
Good sons!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten dharmas have minds free from doubt.
Furthermore, good sons!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten kinds of dharmas attain wisdom like the ocean.
What are the ten?
First, attaining a place like a treasure;
Second, being very deep and difficult to cross;
Third, being vast and immeasurable;
Fourth, gradually becoming deeper in accordance with [the current];
Fifth, not dwelling together with the corpse of afflictions;
Sixth, all having the same flavor;
Seventh, accommodating swift currents;
Eighth, the tide not passing the time;
Ninth, being the support for great beings;
Tenth, being inexhaustible.
How do bodhisattvas attain a place like a treasure?
Good sons!
It is like how the great ocean has treasure sites that people from JambudvÄ«pa all come to obtain treasures, yet they are never exhausted.
Bodhisattvas are like this, with a treasure trove of merit and virtue, and all sentient beings take the treasure of merit and virtue from it without ever exhausting it.
How are bodhisattvas profound and difficult to fathom?
Good man!
It is like the great ocean, which is profound and difficult to fathom.
Bodhisattvas are like this, accomplishing the profound ocean of wisdom, which all sentient beings are unable to cross.
How are bodhisattvas vast and immeasurable?
Good man!
It is like the great ocean, which is vast and boundless.
Bodhisattvas are like this, with the ocean of wisdom vast and boundless.
How are bodhisattvas gradually deepening in accordance with [the Dharma]?
Good man!
It is like the great ocean, which gradually slopes downward and becomes gradually deeper.
Bodhisattvas are like this, with the ocean of omniscience gradually deepening in accordance with the nature of reality.
How do bodhisattvas not dwell together with the corpse of afflictions?
Good man!
It is like the great ocean, which does not retain dead bodies.
Why is it so?
Because the nature of the ocean is such.
In the same way, the bodhisattva does not dwell together with the corpse of afflictions.
Why is it so?
Because the Dharma of the bodhisattva is such.
How are bodhisattvas all of the same flavor?
Good man!
It is like the great ocean, into which all the rushing waters pour, and they all become of the same salty flavor.
In the same way, the bodhisattva accumulates immeasurable pure dharmas and reaches omniscience, all becoming of the same flavor as omniscience.
How are bodhisattvas like rushing currents?
Good man!
It is like the great ocean, which can contain immeasurable rushing waters without increase or decrease.
In the same way, the bodhisattva can contain immeasurable rushing currents of the Dharma rain without increase or decrease.
How are bodhisattvas like tides that do not miss the time?
Good man!
It is like the great ocean, whose tides do not miss the time.
Bodhisattvas are like this, teaching sentient beings according to their faculties, never missing the right time.
How do bodhisattvas become a support for great beings?
It is like the great ocean being a support for great beings.
Bodhisattvas are like this, being a support for all sentient beings' pure wholesome dharmas.
How do bodhisattvas attain inexhaustibility?
Good man!
It is like the great ocean being drawn by all sentient beings, its water being inexhaustible.
Bodhisattvas are like this, teaching the Dharma in various ways for sentient beings without end.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten dharmas attain wisdom like the ocean.
Furthermore, good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten dharmas attain skillful means of subtle wisdom.
What are the ten?
First, attaining skillful means of seeking liberation;
Second, attaining skillful means in thoroughly understanding all dharmas;
Third, attaining skillful means in realizing the equality of all dharmas;
Fourth, attaining skillful means in realizing the illusory nature of all dharmas;
Fifth, attaining skillful means in fully understanding all dharmas;
Sixth, attaining skillful means in the profound and difficult to fathom dependent origination;
Seventh, attaining skillful means in the inconceivability of karma;
Eighth, attaining skillful means in understanding the meaning of the teachings as they are spoken;ğŸ”½Ninth, attaining skillful means in realizing the true meaning as it is;
Tenth, attaining skillful means in the truth.
Good man!
How do bodhisattvas attain skillful means in seeking liberation, up to how do they attain skillful means in the truth?

It is said that this bodhisattva observes that all sentient beings in the world are always burned by greed and desire, confused by anger and hatred, and blinded by the darkness of ignorance and delusion. The bodhisattva thinks like this:
'How can these sentient beings skillfully attain liberation?'
The bodhisattva, for their sake, aspires to penetrate all dharmas.
By penetrating them, he realizes the equality of all dharmas;
By realizing this, he understands the characteristics of illusion;
By understanding this, he thoroughly knows all dharmas as they really are;
By knowing this, he contemplates the profound dependent origination in accordance with it;
By contemplating this, he observes the inconceivable nature of karma in accordance with it.
The bodhisattva contemplates in this way:
'In all dharmas, there is absolutely no reality, yet karma has various differences.'
Because of this, the bodhisattva is able to realize subtle wisdom, and when he hears the essential teachings from the buddhas and bodhisattvas, he immediately understands their meaning;
By understanding the meaning, he sees the truth;
By seeing the truth, he delivers sentient beings from the ocean of birth and death.
Good man!
This is called the bodhisattva's attainment of skillful means in seeking liberation, up to the attainment of true skillful means.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten dharmas attain subtle wisdom.
Furthermore, good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten kinds of dharmas attain appropriate eloquence.
What are the ten?
First, in all dharmas, they establish selflessness;
Second, there are no sentient beings;
Third, there are no living beings;
Fourth, there are no persons;
Fifth, there are no pudgalas;
Sixth, they are far removed from doers and receivers;
Seventh, they are far removed from knowers and seers;
Eighth, they are empty, without anything, without a master;
Ninth, they are empty of false discrimination;
Tenth, all dharmas are established as arising from conditions.
Good man!

Because all dharmas are without self, without sentient beings, without life, without nourishment, without pudgala, far removed from doer and receiver, far removed from knower and seer, empty, inexistent, and without owner, falsely discriminated and produced from conditions. In this way, one should accord with the nature of dharmas.
Good sons!

All that should accord with the nature of dharmas, the nature of dharmas that is not in conflict, the nature of dharmas that is in harmony, the nature of dharmas that is to be realized, and the nature of dharmas that is to be clearly understood - the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva should thoroughly understand all these natures of dharmas. This is called eloquence.
Good sons!
The bodhisattva who accomplishes these ten kinds of dharmas attains eloquent eloquence.
Furthermore, good sons!
The bodhisattva who accomplishes ten kinds of dharmas attains liberated eloquence.
What are the ten?
First, attaining unattached eloquence;
second, attaining inexhaustible eloquence;
third, attaining awakened eloquence;
fourth, to attain fearless eloquence;
fifth, to attain humble eloquence;
sixth, to attain fearless eloquence;
seventh, to attain uncommon eloquence;
eighth, to attain unobstructed eloquence;ğŸ”½ninth, to attain boundless eloquence;
tenth, to attain unobstructed eloquence.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who accomplish these ten qualities attain liberated eloquence.
Furthermore, good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten qualities attain pure eloquence.
What are the ten?ğŸ”½First, to attain eloquence free from hoarseness;
second, to attain eloquence free from confusion;
third, to attain eloquence free from inferiority;
fourth, to attain eloquence free from arrogance;
fifth, to attain eloquence that does not lose meaning;
sixth, to attain eloquence that does not belittle letters;
seventh, to attain eloquence that does not belittle skillful means;
eighth, eloquence that is not inferior when speaking;
ninth, eloquence that is not coarse or harsh;
tenth, eloquence that is clear and distinct.
Good man!
Because bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are free from fear in the midst of assemblies, they attain eloquence that is not hoarse or croaking.
Because they abide in wisdom, they attain eloquence that is not confused.
Because bodhisattvas are fearless in the midst of assemblies, like the king of lions, they attain eloquence that is not inferior.
Because they are free from afflictions, they attain eloquence that is not arrogant.
Good man!
Those with afflictions are arrogant, but those without afflictions are not arrogant.
Because they realize the nature of dharmas, they attain eloquence that does not lose the meaning.
Good man!
Those who have not realized the Dharma lose the meaning, but those who have attained it do not lose it.
Because they are fearless in all discussions, they attain eloquence that is not inferior in terms of written language.
Good man!
Those who know a small portion of discourse will regress in their written words, but those who know all discourses are not called inferior.
Because they accumulate various skillful means, they attain skillful and non-inferior eloquence.
Those without skillful means will regress in their skillful means, but those with skillful means are not inferior.
Good man!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas know long periods of time, know appropriate times, know the beginning, middle, and end, do not speak first and then later, do not speak later and then first, but speak at the appropriate time, thus attaining timely and non-inferior eloquence.
Because they are forever free from verbal disputation, they attain non-harsh eloquence.
Good man!
Those with disputation are called harsh, those without disputation are not harsh.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas attain clear eloquence because their faculties are sharp.
Those with dull faculties are not clear;
Those who are not sharp-witted are unclear.
Good sons!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten qualities attain pure eloquence.
Furthermore, good sons!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten qualities attain the satisfaction of delighting all beings.
What are the ten?
First, attaining endearing speech;
Second, smiling with the mouth, far from frowning;
Third, being able to expound the meaning;
Fourth, being able to expound the Dharma;
Fifth, being able to speak equally;
Sixth, being without arrogance;
Seventh, being far from contempt;
Eighth, being unstained;
Ninth, being without anger;
Tenth, attaining various kinds of eloquence.
Good sons!
What is meant by attaining endearing speech?
Because the bodhisattva's words can delight the minds of sentient beings.
What is meant by smiling with the mouth?
Bodhisattvas have kind countenances and comfort, able to bring peace and security to sentient beings.
How are they able to expound the meaning?
Bodhisattvas speak in a measured way.
How are they able to expound the Dharma?
Bodhisattvas speak for the benefit of sentient beings.
How do they speak equally?
Bodhisattvas always use an impartial mind to teach the Dharma to sentient beings.
How are they free from arrogance?
Bodhisattvas are free from conceit and arrogance, due to their nature of being the same as all beings.
How are they free from contempt?
Bodhisattvas speak the Dharma with respect for the Dharma.
How are they free from defilements?
Bodhisattvas have extremely pure morality.
How are they free from anger?
Bodhisattvas naturally practice patience.
How do they attain various kinds of eloquence?
Bodhisattvas have beautiful and wonderful speech that delights sentient beings.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten qualities are able to bring joy and satisfaction to sentient beings.
Moreover, good sons!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten kinds of dharmas can cause sentient beings to understand what is said.
What are the ten?
First, not teaching the Dharma to those who are not suitable vessels;
Second, not teaching the Dharma to those who are angry and harmful;
Third, not teaching the Dharma to those with excessive pride;
Fourth, not teaching the Dharma to non-Buddhists;
Fifth, not teaching the Dharma to those who do not give rise to respect;
Sixth, not teaching the Dharma to those who lack pure faith;
Seventh, not teaching the Dharma to those who are deceitful;
Eighth, not teaching the Dharma to those who love to pursue a livelihood;
Ninth, not teaching the Dharma to those who are entangled in seeking profit, gaining others' respect, jealousy, and stinginess;
Tenth, not teaching the Dharma to those who are dull-witted, mute, or dumb.
Why is it so?
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas do not not teach the Dharma out of stinginess with the Dharma;
Nor do they keep it secret and not explain it out of fear of becoming the teacher's equal;
Nor do they not explain it out of contempt for sentient beings, nor out of a desire to abandon the Dharma, but only because they are not suitable vessels for the Dharma.
Bodhisattva Nivaraá¹‡aviá¹£kambhin addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
For what kind of sentient beings do the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas explain the Dharma?
The Buddha said:
Good man!

If sentient beings are endowed with the root of faith, are mature Dharma vessels, serve the Buddhas, have no deceitfulness in mind, no deception, no pretense in deportment, are not greedy for offerings, have perfect intentions, are good men, awaken upon hearing the Dharma, are well able to understand, are intelligent and sharp-witted, are able to understand the meaning of what is explained, and diligently cultivate and practice in order to attain the Dharma, and practice in accordance with the TathÄgata's teachings.
Good man!
For sentient beings of this kind, the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas explain the Dharma.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten dharmas are able to receive the teachings.
Furthermore, good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten dharmas are able to be teachers who expound the Dharma.
What are the ten?
First, in order to accumulate the Buddha Dharma, they are able to expound the Dharma, yet the Buddha Dharma is unobtainable, and accumulation is also unobtainable;
Second, in order to accumulate the perfections, they expound the Dharma, yet the perfections are unobtainable, and accumulation is also unobtainable;
Third, in order to accumulate enlightenment, they expound the Dharma, yet enlightenment is unobtainable, and accumulation is also unobtainable;
Fourth, in order to sever afflictions, they expound the Dharma, yet afflictions are unobtainable, and severing them is also unobtainable;

Fifth, they expound the Dharma in order to be disgusted with greed, to be free from greed, and to extinguish greed, yet being disgusted with, being free from, and extinguishing greed are all unobtainable;
Sixth, they expound the Dharma in order to attain the stage of stream-enterer, once-returner, and non-returner, yet the stages of stream-enterer, once-returner, and non-returner are all unobtainable;
Seventh, they expound the Dharma in order to attain the stage of arhat and the fruit of arhatship, yet the stage of arhat and the fruit of arhatship are both unobtainable;

Eighth, they expound the Dharma in order to attain the stage of pratyekabuddha and the fruit of pratyekabuddhahood, yet the stage of pratyekabuddha and the fruit of pratyekabuddhahood are both unobtainable;
Ninth, they expound the Dharma in order to permanently sever attachment to the self, yet the self and attachment are both unobtainable;
Tenth, they expound the Dharma in order to reveal karma and its ripening, yet karma and its ripening are both unobtainable.
Why is this?
Those bodhisattvas think like this:
